questions.question_text: A security administrator needs to block a TCP connection using the corporate firewall. Because this connection is potentially a threat, the administrator does not want to send back an RST. Which of the following actions in the firewall rule would work BEST?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A: Drop it like it's hot (Snoop Dogg)

Selected Answer: A
"In the Drop action, no message is sent describing why the package was dropped. In the Reject action, a message is sent to the source describing the reason for the rejection"

comments.content: Drop is like leaving someone on "seen"

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
"Drop" is stealthier, as the attacker wouldn't be certain if a TCP connection is established, making him/her assume the target system is unresponsive and experiencing network issues.

Selected Answer: A
The "Drop" action in the firewall rule is the best choice to block a TCP connection without sending back an RST (Reset) packet. When a firewall rule is configured to "Drop" a connection, it silently discards the packets without sending any response back to the sender. This approach effectively blocks the connection without providing any indication to the sender that the connection attempt was blocked.

Selected Answer: A
Dropping will not sent a RST flag. Rejecting will

Despite what Gravoc says, the answer is still A. A container is not just a text file. The text file defines the layers of the container. These layers are applied on top of the running host kernel, and provide a base os, any required libraries and associated applications, management tools (text editor, cli tools, etc), and finally the application code is layered on top. Some containers can consist of several gigabytes of stuff across several layers. For example a web application may have a base OS (alpine linux is common), then the Apache web server image, then perhaps an NGIX reverse proxy image, and finally the application image. If a new Apache version is released, simply rebuilding the image and restarting it will incorporate the changes and address any patched vulnerablities.
